GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRÆUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL UNIVERSITY
div.p: The programme of the founders of the proposed National University should have the effect of modifying the criticisms passed in advance upon that institution. The fears to which some of our Egyptophobes—for there ar: Egyptophobes as well as Anglophobes to be found in Cairo and Alexandria-gave utterance, presaging a "Nationalist" University with Miata as Pasha Kamel or some vigorous and intolerant member of the olema class as its R:otor, are shown to be groundlees, and the pronouncement of the committee that the doors of the new University shall be thowa oj on to all, whatever their origin and their religion, who desire to learn, and that its constitution shall be entirely independent of political ir flaenops, is reassuring. Nor is the programme of the University courses too restricted, while none can accuse it of a lack of idealism. In fact, even some of the sympathisers with the movement may feel a certain doubt whether those who have drawn up the programme may not have sought to soar, like Icarus, too near the sun on their first flight. But we should like to remind our readers that Kassim Bey Amin's letter does not contain a definite programme : the University will not open to-morrow, nor will students crowd to Cairo this winter to attend its lectures. Some years of patient work are required before the University can be finally established. Funds must be raised and a site must be chosen.

The constitution of the governing body must be determined, and professors discovered, who are capable of teaching Oriental students. We will refer later to some of these points, Mean-
London,
Salisbury Hotel,
Fleet Street, E.C.
Inclusive Terms 10/6 per Day.
English service and catering.
Under personal supervision of
Mr. and Mrs. T. BARTENS.
time, we must realise that we have to do with a very admirable and public-spirited proposal made by men who ze spirit ia progressive, whose enthusiasm is unbounded, and whose aims are free from the taint of self interest. To those who assert that the motives of the promoters of the scheme are interested, we reply that if the University is to be a successful and well-organized foundation, there will be no room for private profit. The founders will, indeed, obtain some of the immaterial rewards of public spirit--the criticism of the ignorant and the praise of the enlightened : but, even should their first essay be unfruitful, their names will be famous among their compatriots and also among all men whom love of knowledge and admiration of a genuinely patriotic spirit render indifferent to the distinctions of creed and race. And in the days to come such men will abound.

Our critics--we foresee their appearance--may deny our premises. But, after all, if they assert that the scheme will founder through disunion, they must remember that the newborn zeal for education may yet carry Egyptians safely past the Scylla of jealousy and the Charybdis of intrigue, and if they want that the scheme is doomed to fall into dishonest hands, we--can only reply that if the University Committee diverts the subscriptions it will receive into improper channels, and not only we but all Egypt--are absolutely mistaken in our judgment of the honesty and single-mindedness of its members.

We have remarked that the programme which Kassab Bey Amin bas suggested and outlined may not meet with the approval of all the world. But it is capable of modification, and if the public to which it is addressed has criticism to offer, none can doubt that ita criticisms will have weight. Bat we should like to point out that till now the corse of Egyptian education has been the view taken by and Moslems alike, that education exists b enable young men to obtain positions order Government or to crowd certain professions that once were lucrative but are now over-crowded by the multitude of competitors. Wo admit that education in the present state of society must be for most a means to such an e.d. Batman shall not live by bread alone. "The nations have succeeded best which have aimed as far as possible at a wide training—the training of the mind and of the body, and the training of the will. China is the classic instance of failure, dae not so much to the predominance of a purely literary education, as to the prevalence of the idea that the be all and end-all of education was the supply of mandarins. France and England at the present day, Rome and Greece in the past, have realised that such over-specialisation is almost as dangerous as neglect to the body politic, that education when possible must be something more than a means to wealth.

Et propter vitam vivendi perdere causas applies too well to an education that is concentrated on the production of money-makers.. A modern State does not require citizens turned out like coin from a mint-aniform, stamped with the same pattern and the same milling. It needs numbers and variety, specialists and handicraftsman, active workers and watchful critics ; even the idle rich-pace our Socialista -have their value once their intellects or their characters or both have been disciplined or trained. A millionaire may devote his wealth to the advancement of knowledge ; a poor man may become a leader in the councils of his people.

Thus far neither the Egyptian Government nor the Egyptian people have had the time or the means to create a University. A system of secɔndary "and technical education has achieved much, bat it hus not given-por in the nature of things could it give-the opportunity to zealous students of acquiring a wider knowledge. The young Egyptian of means has too often fallen a victim to his own indolence. His secondary studies completed, he has seized on the absence of any system of higher education as an excuse for apathy, has learnt nothing new, and forgotten all be has already learnt. The unemployed (or ill-employed) rich abound among as. If the new scheme finds intellectual employment for even a section of them, it will have done much.

It will have done more if it succeeds in imbuing the average man with the idea that his education is not necessarily finished because he can make L.E. 5 a month; it will have fulfilled the aspirations of its founders is it can produce soholars who are in touch with practical life and practical men, whose natural eagerness for self improvement is mellowed and refined by a genuine love of knowledge.

We wish the committee rapid and complete BUCO889. If they can work together, if they can overcome jealousy and mistrust, if they 032 overcome that inertia which is a deadlier foe than active opposition, they must succeed. And their success may have far-reaching effects. What happier fate could be in store for Egypt if at the very gate-way of the East thore srose a University destined to harmonise East with West, to be in concord with the proud and. maply spirit of lelam, the ideas that , Greece, and Rome have handed down to the Western world?

div.head: Egyptian Camblers.
div.p: It is estimated that the Egyptian "jeunesse dorée" have lost L.E. 200,000 in gambling this season at Vichy.

div.head: The Midday Gun.
div.p: The noon gun at Cairo Citadel was not fired on Monday owing to the snapping of the electric wire between it and the Observatory.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Today's bulletin reports the admission to hospital at Alexandria of a Greek waiter belonging to a café in the Gumruk quarter as a case of bubonic plague.

div.head: Theft of L.E. 800.
div.p: "Al-Mokattam" publishes a telegram from its Tala correspondent stating that the sum of LE. 800 has been stolen from the Tala Markaz cashier at Batanoun.

div.head: Luxor Chaplaincy.
div.p: The new Anglican chaplain at Luxor is the Rev. Mr. Saens. The Rav. Grose, the former chaplain, is not coming out this year, having taken an appointment in Switzerland.

div.head: Public Health Dept.
div.p: Dimitri A. Acholos, Nicolas O. Catsaras, Constantin A. Mantzelopoulos, and Yasseuh Nessim Jacque have been authorised to practise as physicians, and M. Jacques A. Rentzos as pharmacist.

div.head: Wakfs Board.
div.p: A meeting of the Wakfs Board will be held in Cairo this afternoon under the presidency of Ahmed Shafik Bey, chief of the Khedive's Bureau.

div.head: The French Consulate.
div.p: M. de Raffye has postponed the first sitting of the French Consular Court, Cairo, for the trial of civil cases and charges of misdemeanour antil the middle of November.

div.head: Fatal Cart Accident.
div.p: At Hagar Nawatieh, Ramleh, yesterday, a native youth was run over by a vegetable cart, and sustained injuries to which he succumbed this morning.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The P. & O.S.S. Osiris arrived at Port Said at nine o'clock this morning with mails from Europe. The distribution at the G. P. O., Alexandria, will commence at 9 o'clock this evening.

div.head: Land for State Railways.
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways Administration has deposited the sum of L.E. 14.500 with the Native Tribunal of First Instance for the expropriation of lands at Miniet el Sirg.

div.head: Khedivial Agricultural Society.
div.p: The British barque Heathfield (Captain Fraser) is discharging a cargo of about 2,800 tons of nitrate of soda for the Khedivial Agricultural Society from Iquique, Chili, which she left just before the recent terrible earthquake.

div.head: Agricultural Bank Bonds.
div.p: The National Bank of Egypt announces that scrip of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt three and a half per cent. guaranteed bonds may now be exchanged for definitive bonds to bearer. Scrip must be listed on forms to be obtained from the National Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5, King William-street, E. C., and left three clear days for examination.

div.head: Naval Funeral.
div.p: First-class Domestic R.Cole,of H.M.S. Venus, whose death we recorded yesterday, was buried at the British Protestant Cemetery, Rosetta Gate, this morning. The mortal remains of the deceased were accompanied to the cemetery by a firing party from the craiser and the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers.

div.head: Post Office Savings Bank.
div.p: During the month of September 1,129 per. sons deposited the sum of L.E. 33,500 in the Post Office savings bank, which, added to the sum-remaining io the bank on the first of that month, gives a total of L.E. 322,822. During the same month L.E. 28,733 were withdrawn, 80 that the balance due to depositors on the 1st September was L.E. 294,089.

div.head: New Large Jewish School.
div.p: Five, and a half feddans of land on the Pyramide-road, near El Talabieh, have been sold for £6,400 by a group of Israelites, whose object is to erect a large school for the teaching of commerce, industries, and agriculture, and the primary education of Jewish children. M. Lietto Acher has presented a house valued at £1,600 for the same purpose.

div.head: Arrivals.
div.p: The steamers from Europe are arriving here full; it is said that never before have there been so many arrivals. A good many of the passengers have taken advantage of their sojourn in France, Italy, England, or Germany to improve their knowledge of the languages of those countries. They will resume the lessons begun in the Berlitz Schools of Europe either in Cairo (Sharia Kamel) or in Alexandria (12 rue Rosette), and they will not notice the least change in the method, for it is exactly the same everywhere. [Advt.]

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria) half way to San Stefano

div.head:
EGYPT'S DEMAND FOR MONEY.
LONDON OPINION.
div.p: The way in which the London money market has been drained to meet the Egyptian demand lead the "Statist" to remark :- "It is too early yet to estimate with any confidence the probable Egyptian demand. Until recently that demand was expected to be emall, because speculation is much less active than it was at this time last year. Now opinion has changed, and it is feared that the demand will be large. Quite possibly, in a little time farther we may see another change of opinion, or the Bank of France may decide upon supplying Egypt freely. It would not be wise, however, to depend upon that. Ever since 1870 the policy of the Bank of France has been to keep as large an amount of gold as it possibly can. Just now there are many reasons why the Bank of France should think it desirable to maintain that policy. The State of Russia, the general distur. bance of the political equilibrium in Europe, the uprost among the Mohamedans, and the uneasiness at home, pre-all reasons why the Bank of France should think it desirable to part with very large amounts. It is true that there has been a very considerable decrease in the gold held by the Bank of France. But then it is not possible from the returns to ascertain to what extent that decrease is for internal and to what extent for external requirements. Therefore for the present it would be best to assume that the Egyptian demand upon this country - will be nearly as large as in recent years."

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RETURN.
div.p: Our Port. Said Correspondent telegraphs that Lord Cromer arrived there by the P. and O. steamer Osiris this morning, and left by special train for Cairo, where he is due to arrive at 4-pm.

Hafiz Eff. Ibrahim, the wall-known native poet, intends to submit to Lord Cromer an Arabic poem which he has composed, relating to the various events which have occurred in Egypt during his lordship’s absence. The poet points on that the Egyptians have not changed and never will, but the charge brought against them after the Denishwai incident was a bitter pill for them. Addressing his stanzas to Lord Cromer, the poet adds: "Had you been here to see the Donishwai affair people would not have been tortured."

div.head: FRONTIER COMMISION.
div.p: The Nuhr el Bahr has left Saez for Akaba, where she will probably embark those members of the Frontier Commission who are returning by sea to Suez.

div.head: NEW BARRACKS FOR ABASSIEH.
div.p: A board of officers is to meet at Headquarters, Cairo, on Thursday next in order to consider the question of the site and the construction of barracks for the Army of Occupation at Abbassieh. The board will be composed of Col. G. J. Cuthbert, A.A.G., president, Col. J. Magill, M.D., C.B., R.A.M.C., Col. A. W. Roper, R.E., and Lieut. Col. E. A. Herbert, M.V.O., Inniskilling Dragoons.

div.head: SALE OF SIRDAR'S ISLAND
div.p: Atran Island, commonly known as Sirdar's Island, which was bought from Lord Kitohener some four years ago by Mr. G.D. Faber, C.B., junior Member of Parliament for York, has been sold to the Government for L.B. 9,000. Atron Island, situated on the Nile at Assouan, is the most beautiful of Egypt's isles; and is very rich in cultivation. It covers an area of over ten feddans.

div.head: LOTTERY CIRCULARS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The introduction of a penny post between England and Egypt has led to the practice of despatching Hungarian lottery circulars to Englald via Alexandria. The postage from Hungary would be twopence half penny, and as the circulars are sent off in quantities of 50,000 or more at a time the Bada-Pesth lottery mongers can effect & very substantial saving by forwarding them in balk to be posted here. It is hoped that the Postmaster General in England will ascertain whether Lord Cromer cannot put a stop to this misuse of the Egyptian Post Office.

div.head: MOHAMEDAN RIGHTS IN INDIA.
div.p: The Mahomedan community in India, as represented by their delegates at Simla, since presenting their memorial to the Viceroy, have been discussing the best means for safeguarding their interests. It has been decided, in the first place, to organize provincial associations which should send representatives to a central body. The further organization of the scheme, particularly with reference to that body and its functions, will be discussed at Dacca, where the annual Mahomedan educational conference assembles in December. The main object is to keep the Government authoritatively informed as to local Mahomedan feelings and aspirations. Methods of agitation such as those employed by the National Congress will be carefully avoided.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: Messrs. Collinge Brothers cable as follows:-- Weekly Bureau Crop accounts generally onfa. vourable ; too much rain and frost.

div.head:
MARBURG V. ADAMS.
DISORDERLY CONDUCT IN CAIRO
div.p: Yesterday morning, the hearing of a summons brought by Mr. Marburg, proprietor of the St. James's Hotel, against Mrs. Adams took place at H.B.M.'s Consular Court, Cairo. The defendant was represented by Maitre Geoffrey Miward.

It appears that a few days ago, Mrs. Adama's little daughter entered the St. James's Hotel, where she fell into conversation with a couple of officers, who gave her ices, sweets, etc. And appears to have become , rather excited, and eventually began to throw ices from the window of the hotel on to the beads of those who were having supper below. This conduct naturally provoked a scene, and the child - was requested to leave the hotel, the proprietor of which giving orders that she should not be admitted in future.

On the following evening Mrs. Adams appeared, and sitting down at a table which was already occupied, began to talk loudly, to the diners, who seem to have objected, and Mrs. Adams was ordered to leave the hotel. At about three o'clock in the morning, she re-appeared, driving up in company with her husband and daughter, and entered the, hotel, where she created considerable distarbanos, violently abusing Mr. Marburg, who was eventually obliged to send for a policeman. Mrs. Adams was then removed, loudly protesting, and drove away. She afterwards returned, however, and for some time drove up and down in front of the hotel, uttering loud and free comments on the conduct of the proprietor. Her defence was that she had sent her daughter on the previous day to find a doctor, who she believed was having supper there, to ask him to come at once to visit her husband, who was seriously ill. The Court criticised the defence on the grounds that Mr. Adams's illness was not so serious as to prevent him from going on a moonlight drive with his wife and daughter. Mrs. Adams was fined £2.

div.head:
AFTER DENISHWAI.
SIGNIFICANT MOVE OF TROOPS.
div.p: The "Moayad" reports that a detachment of the British Army of Occupation will march from Cairo to Shibin el-Kom on the 20th inst. "The troops will be encamped there for several days. The Menonfieh mondirieb, having received orders to prepare a site for the camp, has selected a plot of land about 8 feddans in extent situated outside the town.
The inhabitants of Menoufieh, on hearing of the contemplated visit of the troops, have been much perturbed, and are in hopes that it is for no other reason than the exercising of the troops.
We understand that the rumour that the troops are to be permanently stationed at Shibin el Kom is absolutely without foundation.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: On the occasion of the commencement of the month of Ramadan H.H. the Khedive, will hold on Friday a reception at Ras-el-Tin, to take place in the following order :--
8 p.m - The Ulema ; the Princes of the Khedivial Family ; the heads of State administrations.
8.30 p.m.-The magistrates of the Mixed Tribunals ; the magistrates of the Native Tribunals ; the officers of the Army and Navy of the rank of Bimbashi and upwards ; the civil officials.

9 p.m.--Civil and military non officials, with the ranks of Lewa or Oula Sinf Sani, and upwards ; officers of the Army and Navy retired or en disponibilité. with the rank of Miralai or Kaimakam ; non-official Beys with the rank of Montemaiz or Sapieh ; the members of the Municipal Commission.
9.30 p.m.--Native merchants ; the civil and military household of H.A. the Khedive and the Khedivial Khassa.
The reception is exclusively reserved for persons resident at Alexandria. - The military will attend in undress uniform and civilians in frockcoats (redingotes).

Civil officials admitted to this reception must have at least the rank of sub direotor (or an equivalent rank) and the grade of Sanieh,or Kaimakam (military), as well as magistrates nominated by decree.
Her Highness the Khedivah will receive the same day, between 8 and 10 p.m., the Princesses of the Khedivial Family and native ladies only.

div.head: THE LATE PRINCE MOHAMED.
div.p: The "Mokattam” says that Lord Cromer has telegraphed to those concerned with the appointment of a tutor to the obildren of the late Prince Mobamed Ibrahim asking them to postpone any decision until his return.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN UNIVERSITY.
div.p: The provisional committee of the proposed Egyptian University has published a second list or fourteen subscribers, whose contributions amount to L.E. 2,350. The subscriptions now total L.E. 6,985. M. Lietto Acher, a well known member of the Jewish community in Cairo, has offered £200.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light

div.head:
"AL MINBAR."
REPLY TO OUR CRITICISM.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,--I hope I shall not be trespassing unduly on your valuable space by replying to the arguments adduced to support the view that "Al. Minbar" is of a "dangerous character," and that by reason thereof the authorities were justified in prohibiting its entry into the Sadan. I should in the first instance point out that the term "suppressed," in that relation, was erroneously employed, seeing that no copy of our publication had ever been sent into the Sudan. Permission' was asked soon after our journal made its appearance to authorise its transmission in the Sudan; and that permission has recently been refused upon no stated grounds, though it is clear that those responsible thought it inexpedient to let the paper into circulation. With this decision I do not quarrel, because I have no doubt that it was sincerely arrived at, but what I do regret is that the authorities should not have taken care to be better informed. Had they been able to read our articles in the original instead of being obliged to trust to others less scrupulous and honourable than themselves, it would, I doubt not, have been patent to them that "Al Minbar," far from being inimical to their interests, has from the first initiated a policy favourable to them. Speaking at the dinner given by the Press to Major Owen Bey on the occasion of our return from the opening of the Nile-Red-Sea Railway, and subsequently on more than one occasion in print, I expressed the opinion that the Sodan should be regarded as part and parcel of Greater Egypt and that the interests of the two are indissolubly bound ap together. So, too, as regards the question of Egypt's contribution towards the expenditure in the Sudan. "Al Minbar” bas invariably upheld the present arrangement on the grounds just stated, namely, that the two countries should be regarded as forming an integral. Can those views be regarded as in any sense "dangerous ?” But to come to matters more immediately at issue. "Al Minbar” is accused of having disseminated a statement by an anonymous German attributing to the English the invention of cholera and plague without at once contradicting it. The answer is simply this: The report was that of an interview with A well-known German Orientalist who did not wish his name disclosed. Now I would ask. Is it necessary to criticise in every such casei I should say not. To take the most recent instance : "The Pall Mall Gazette" published a lengthy report of an interview between its Paris correspondent and the editor of "El Lewa" containing maný statements, which, from the English point of view, were "exceedingly dangerous" and the report of the interview was reproduced in "The Egyptian Gazette" on the 12th inst. In neither instance was any editorial comment appended thereto. I could oite hundreds of other instances of an identical description. It must, therefore, I think, be taken as clear that an editor is not bound to deny every statement published in his paper on the authority of a third party, which he knows or has reasonable grounds for believing to be untrue, and hence that accusation falls to the ground. But "Al Minbar" is farther charged with unduly eulogising the Ottoman Empire. All that I ogn say, in reply, is that whilst acknowledging H.I.M. the Sultan as the Khalif of Islam, and expressing our loyalty to the Khalilate, we have never forgotten to point out the reactionary tendencies of the present Turkish Government, which like other governments will have its time and pass away. And how could it be possible for any mind endowed with a semblance of logio to ask in one breath for perfect, liberty and equality on behalf of the Egyptians without at the same time condemning the autocratic Government in Turkey? The thing is manifestly absurd.

"Al Minbar's" policy has throughout been "Egypt for the Egyptians." To show that we have maintained that view I beg leave to quote from a leading article in "Al Minbar” of the 24th July last in which the following passage occurs :- "The Egyptians desire to be independent without being under any autocrat either in Yildiz, Abdin, or Kasr El Doubara.” Of course we at the same time defend the integrity of the Turkish Empire and desire to see it regenerated and strong again amongst the nations of the world. Again we say that no one who has a grain of political sense or experience can doubt that for Egypt to become again a Turkish vilayet, as it was before the time of Mohamed Aly, would be the graves of all misfortunes for one country. The legation that our journal charged British cons and missionaries with instigating the Armeans to rebel is without foundation. The rmeniang -wore dover referred to by ng at all a this connection.

The last of the suggestions made against "A Minbar," namely, that it is not allowed to enter Turkey, is in reality an answer to a previous criticism, viz, that "Al Minbar” has Turkish proclivities. Our journal has never been circulation in Turkey from the very fact that we do not send any copies unless required by subscribers and newsvendors. The same is the case as regards Tanie, Algeria, etc.

I think I have now dealt with all the points raise. It only remains for me to add that in writing the above and the previous letter which you did me the honour to insert I wish to be understood that the explanations giver are not intended to conciliate anybody or win a view to make it appear that our policy needs justification. My object has been solely to correct misunderstandings and remove erroneous assumptions engendering friction which it is in the interests of all to avoid. In conclass I wish to express the gratitude of my co e for and myself for the invaluable support Recorded to us by The Egyptian Gazette," in our campaign against corruption in the Irrigation Department,
Apologising for the length of this letter, I ,
A. HAFIZ AWAD
Editor-Propr, of "Al Minbar.”

div.head:
ANCIENT EGYPT.
PRIMITIVE PICTURE WRITING.
div.p: A very important essay relating to the primitive art and culture of the ancient Egyptians is that of M. George Fouoart, "Sur la Decoration des Vases de la période dite de Naggadeh," read by him before the French Academy.

The subject, as stated by M. Foucart, does not include all the pictorial ornamental styles upon this primitive pottery, but is restricted to an explanation of the meaning of a tableau frequently found, in more or less modified form, and well known to Egyptologiste.

This is a sort of panorama depositing a boat, with elevated prow and stern, containing a kind of naoo, looked at oursorily, appearing to be merely two piles of timber united near their summits by a connecting bridge. From one of the masses of freight or elsewhere on the vessel projects a flagstaff, or guidon pole, bearing emblems; whilst one or more pålma extend from the stern.
In the field of the picture are people with their arms uplifted, or carrying boomerangs, gazelles and large birds, and a few small pyramidal objects, which have been thought to indicate hillocks.

M. Foucart's theory, which is a most in, teresting one, is that these scenes indicata a time when Egyptian writing had not passed out of the pictorial stage. Thøge scenes upon the pottery are in fact trae hieroglyphs, and are really a primitive panoramio display of what subsequently became the verbal proscynom of the funeral stele, which in itself, when for private personages, was but a copy of worship offered daily to the deities in their temples ; and with extra splendour, in these edifices or outside them, at thọ special fêtes of the gods.

The following is M. Foucart's interpretation of the scenes depicted, and it will immediately appear how appositely his theory accounts for them. The boat with its long rows of oars is the "barque divin” which every Egyptian god had in his temple for the purpose of conveying him in a procession on land, or if used only as a symbol of the deity's voyage -across the celestial ocean or river, he embarked upon it and proceeded in procession on the Nile.

The boat emblem therefore conveyed the idea that the fate of a god was intended. Then the double connected pieces of ourgo are a representation of the temple pylons, indicating, therefore, a religious festival proceeding from the deity's earthly mansion.

The pole, or flagstaff, with its particular emblem Alsating from it, explains which god's fête was intended ; and it is most rạmarkable that M. Foucart hus beən able to select from these boat banners at least ten guidons, whose figures he shows are the sacred symbols of as many divinities. These, as might be expected, correspond in most cases with the ancient pome Totem gods we know from other ralios of the very earliest Egyptian art. The one or more palms at the prow or stern of the vessel, indicate the number of days' duration of the festival, whilst the people with hands and arms uplifted acclaim the passage of the sacred barque.

Finally, the deer, † birds, and triangular objects all refer to the great festival sacrifices, and stand, pictorially, for the well-known rubric inscribed, as it was recited, upon the funeral stelæ and temple rituals of later date, which it will be remembered commence by promising a feast of "thousands of gazelles and of birds and loaves, or cakes," these, latter being represented in the vase talleans by the little pyramidal objects.

The stele, texts also inolade (as does the "Pancarte" or "Table of offerings formalæ," a derivative from them) stuffs and vestments, and thậge M. Fougart sometimes finds shown upon the vase drawings standing in bales, especially on pottery found at Naggadeb. So these pictures are the prototypes of the tomb paintings and reliefs; and, which is even more important, they are the pictorial symbolic representation before, the later hieroglyphs developed into the determinatives, and letters of the literary inscriptions upon the funeral stelæ, and finally of the same texts whøn engrossed upon the sepalohral papyri.
JOSEPH OFFORD.

†There appear to be four species of gazelles depicted on the Naggadeh objects, and these therefore correspond to the four gazelles said, in a tomb text at Hieraoonopolis, to be the canonical number to be utilised for sacrifices

div.head: UPPER EGYPT HOTELS CO.
div.p: The Upper Egypt Hotels Company is making rapid progress towards the completion of its now hotel at Luxor, which is . virtually finished and will be opened on New Year's Day. Mr. Pagnon, managing director of the company, arrives at Luxor on Saturday next to pat the finishing touches to this palatial estab: lishment. All the farnitore, and fittings have arrived at Alexandria or are on their way from England. The hotel will accommodate nearly two hundred guests. The company has also been greatly improving its second caravanserai at Luxor, the Luxor Hotel, of old renown, which has baon entirely renovated. At Assouan the Cataract Hotel is being got ready for receiving guests in the course of next month. The company has made some important repairs and renovations in the Savoy Hotel on Elephantine Island. It will be opened in December. The Grand Hotel at Assouan has remained open all the summer and will keep open until the reopening of the Savoy, and Cataract Hotels. Luxor has assumed quite a new aspect since the new hotel, the Winter Palace, has beer built, for by its erection a promenade on the river bank has been created.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We regret to learn of the illness of Princess Saliha Hanem, widow of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim.
Colonel (temporary Major General) George M. Ballook, C.B., Commanding the Army of Occupation in Egypt, has been promoted to the full rank of Major General.

A distinguished member of the Khedivial staff has been home on leave, and has just returned to Egypt, says the "Court Journal," This is Major J. K. Watson, late of the King's Royal Rifles, who is an aide-de-camp.of the Khedive, and the first British officer to be permanently employed in that capacity. Major Watson retired last year after twenty years service, daring sbich he had seen much fighting in Burmah, in the Sudan, in the Dongola and the East expeditions, and in South Africa. In the campaign which culminated in the overthrow of the Mahdi he wag aide.de camp to Lord Kitohener, and in South Africa he acted as his military secretary. Captain Wataon received the D.8 0. for the Dongola expedition, the C.M.G. in 1900, and the M.V.O. last year. He is forty-one and is married to a daughter of Mr. H. C. Nigbet, of the Old House, Wimbledon.
Judge Bond, vice-president of the Native Court of Appeal, is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 20th iost., on his return from England via Port Said.
Judge Batcheller, of the Mixed Court of Appeal, has returned from leave and is now staying at San Stefano.
Adly Pasha Yaghen, Director-General of Wakfs, is expected to return to Cairo from Europe, at the end of this month.
Herr von Wunderlich, German Copsul at Alexandria, is expected to arrive next Monday by the S. S. Hohenzollern.
Mr. Frank Haselden, Mr. and Mrs. Crafton, and Mr. Carver arrived at Alexandria from Port Said this morning by the Khedivial liner Assouan.
Mohamed Bey Ali El-Shadili, Governor of Damietta, has been granted two months and 12 days' leave, to date from the 26th inst.
Mr. George Stevenson, general manager of the Telephone Company, will arrive from Europe to-morrow.
Lient. A. . Wodehouse, 1st Battalion Royal Dáblin Fusiliers, has been granted leave of absence on the recommendation of a medical board for three months.
Mr. R. L. Dalaqais has been elected honorary secretary to the Deutsche Sportsverein.

Mr. Henry S. Wellcome, who established the Wellcome Research Laboratories at the Gordon Memorial College, Khartoum, three years ago, has sent a donation of fifty guineas towards the endowment fund of the London School of Tropical Medicine.
A marriage has been arranged between Mr. Max Stross, son of Mr. Adolph Stross of Alexandria, and Miss Piera Odeiro, Lavaggi, of Genoa.

div.head: COPTS AND MOHAMEDANS.
div.p: A young Coptic student at the Law School, Cairo, has aroused great indignation, among his comrades by his denial of the existence of Mohamed as the Prophet of Islam. His fellow students asked him to give them the statement in writing, which he did, and they then referred the matter to the acting director of the school. He, however, declared that such matters were not within his province and advised the students to take the matter before the Parquet. This advice was followed and the case will be heard shortly.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor arrived at Liverpool last Sunday.
The Ellerman S.S. Arbabian sailed last Sunday from Liverpool with a general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Venice sailed from Malta yesterday noon, and is dae here on Satörday morning next with passengers and a general cargo.
The S.S. Carib Prinos, with passengers and general cargo, loft Malta on the 16th inst., and is due at Alexandria on Saturday morning.
The S.S. Royal Prince left Malta on the 15th inst, with passengers and general cargo, and is . due to arrive at Alexandria on Friday.
The Canard S.S. Pavia sailed direct for Liverpool yesterday afternoon with a fall cargo, including 3,878 bales of cotton.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICPALE.
(Communication Officielle)
div.p: La Délégation Magicipale s'est réanie le 16 Octobre 1906 à 5 h. p.m. sous la présidence de S.E. le Dr. Sshiess Pacha.
La Délégation prend connaissance du projet de règlement élaboré par les services tendant aa recensement de la taxe de 3% chaque quatre années.
Elle émet an avis favorable à ce projet et décide de le communiquer au Comité des finances, avant de le sommettre à la Commission Manicipale.
Elle approave on projet de règlement modi ficatif aux déclarations faire pour les ani, maux et véhicules at décide de le soumettre à l'approbation de la Commission Manicipale.

Sur la demande de la Police, la Délégation proposera à la Commission l'adoption d'an arrêté interdipant aux joueurs d'orgae de barbarie et d'orchestrions de toutes sortes, de faire circuler dans les rues de la ville, d'Alex andrio ou do sa banliene, leurs instramenta ni d'en jouer, de 1 hgore à 4 heures de l'aprèsmidi, ni après 11 heures, darant la nuit.
Ls Délégation charge l'Administrateur de reprendre les démarches auprès des autorité: gouvernementales, pour la cession à la ville des fortifications destinées à la création des parcs Sad.
Elle décide la mise en adjadication des travaux d'ompierrement de la route d'accès aux Prisons.

Communication est donnée d'ane lettre de la Municipalité de Stockport donnant les ren. soignements qui lui ont été demandés au sajet da chasse-corps adopté par les tramways de cette ville. La Délégation décide de communi. quer cette lettre à la Société des Tramway: d'Alexandrie, en loi recommandant l'adoption de os système.

La Délégation prend connaissance de trois lettres de S.E. le Ministra de l'Intérieur, en date du 13 octobre 1906, la première approuvant les crédits votés par la Commission dans sa séance da 3 octobre 1906, la deuxième et la troisième, anspondant aux fins d'examen, les projets de règlements arrêtés par la Com miosion fixent les modes d'avertissement pour les automobiles et byciclettes, et règlant le transport des matières pouvant répandre de la poussière ou exhaler de maavaises odeurs.
"La Délégation rønvoie à l'étude des services techniques une proposition de l’Egyptian Fira Protection Co. pour l'installation d'an poste central & Minet-el-Bassal d'avertisseur d'incen. dies.
L1 Délégation décide de mattre aux enchères Après les fêtes da Baïram, soit les jeudi 22 et et jeudi 29 novembre 1906, les lots suivants des quais :
Parcelles N. 2, No 6, No 13, No 26 et N° 33. La séanco ošt levée à 7 b. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
Auiourd'hui à midi et demie.
div.p: Après un débat en réaction, la cote s'est real à poa relevée à la suite de la hausss accenta és de quelques titres.

L'Union Foncière, qui était négligée depuis longtemps aux environs de 6 livres, vient d'être l'objet d'une forte demande tant locale que du Caire qui a fait monter le prix à 6 5/16. De nombreuses transactions ont éé effectuées à ce cours et l'on s'attend à une cou - tinuation de la hausse, motivée par l'excellente situation de cette société.
Beaucoup d'affaires également en National Bank, Salt & Soda, Cassa di Sconto, Delta Land, Estates et Comptoir.

La Salt and Soda monte de 22/3 & 23/6, la Cassa di Sconto de 233 à 234, Tes Tramway: Privilégiées de 185 à 187, la Bébéra de 38 a 40 vendearg, les Markets de 27/3 à 27/6 ex coupon, et la Nile Land de 16 3/8 & 16 1/2.

Par contre, la Delta Light perd 1/32 à 11 29/32, la Daïra 1/16 à 16 13/16, les lots Tarcz 1 fr. 50 à 146, la Banque d'Athènes 50 centi. mes à 144 1/2, la Delta Lani 1/32 3 3/4, la Comptoir 1/32 & 6 31/32, et la Building Lands 1/32 à 5 1/32.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 16 Octobre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a été élevé bier do 1/4 8 4 7/8 poar cent par snite de nouveaux grande retraits d'or pour l'Egypte. Is

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 86 5/8. et l'Unifiée à 104 1/2. La National Bank a haussé de 5/8 à 27 1/2. L'Agricole est demeurée inchargée à 9 7/8, de même que la Doïra à 17. La Delta Light al encore gagé 1,8 à 12.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a c!o are en avance de 3 francs à 781. La Banque d'Athènes & regagné 1 frano á 145. L'omprant russe 1906 a passé de 83.80 à 84.50.

De même qu'hier, nous avons ea, ce matin, on marché actif et animé des meilleures dis. positions. Los transactions ont été nombreuses et, malgré des réalisations importantes, la demande & constamment primé l'offre. Augbi bien la fermeté a dominé sar toute la ligne et il y a encore à enregistrer des plas-values sur la plupart des prix de olorure de la veille.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na. tional a débuté à 27 3/8 pour fléchir à 27 1/8 Tet o'Oturer & 27 3/16-1/4. L'Agricole & progressé à 9 13/16 7/8 et la Cassa di Sconto à 231-232. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit & 7 1/8 l'action ancienne et 6 15/16 la nouvelló. La Banque d'Abyssinie est revenue à 5 9/16.

L'action Crédit Foncier a été traitée à 780; l'obligation & lots ancienne a molli à 336-337. La Béhéra & avancé à 38 1/4. La Nile Land est restée à 16 1/2; la part de fondateur est retombée à 85. bes Improvements ont atteint £6.
En excellente tendance, l'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux & gagné 1/8 à 4 1/2; la part de fondateur, très recherchée, & hausté à 94.
L'action Allotment s'est raffermie à 3 1/2; la part de fondateur a clôtaré à 132.
L'Union Foncière a été négociée à 6-6 1/16. Le Wardan Estate a faibli à 6 7/8.

La Delta Light a avancé à 11 15/16.12. Les Jouissances Eaux da Caire ont été bien tenues 1 264 265. Les Automobiles ont été cotées 6 5/8 et la part de fondateur 12 1/4. La Frigori. fique a rétrogradé à 4 3/4. L'Anglo-American Nile & progressé à 5 9/16-5/8.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, los Napgovich ont é'é poussés à 18 3/8-7/16. Les Egyptian ont atteint en clôture le prix de £ 7. Les Upper Egypt se sont maintenus à 5 3/16. Les National ont gagné 1/16 À 4 1/16 ; la part de fondateur a passé à 77.

Parmi les petites valeors, c'est la New Egyptian qui & ou encore les honneurs de la matinée. Largement échangéa d'un bout a l'autre de la séance, elle a clôturé entre 84 sh, 9 et 35, gagnant un shelling et demi. Les Del ta Land ont atteint les aborda de 3 15/16 pour réactionner à 3 13/16 et finir plas fermos à 3 7/8. Les Estates se sont consolidés à £2; la part de fondateur a avancé à 13 16/16. Les Markets ont été traités à 27 sh. 6, ex-coupon. Les Constructions ont été cotées 1 1/2-9/16, les Abdy 1 1/4-5/16, le: Glymenopoulo 1 3/8. 7/16, les Khedivial Mail 36 sh. et les Sacreries 25-26 francs. Les Hooker ont été demandés & 1 1/8 sur la romear que le domaine de Goor. bal aurait été finalement vendu. Les Oasis ont progressé à 1 3/16-1/4 et les Salt and Soda à 22 sb.
51 Nous détachons d'ane lettre de Paris, en I date du 9 Octobre, le passage suivant :

Il semble que notró marché abase un peu de la santé da Sultan pour déprimer los cours, de la Rente tarque, ainsi que cotx des va illeurs ottomanes en général. Que le Padischab soit malade, cela ne fait pas de doute ; que, pour ce fait, on impose à cos valeurs one certaine réserve, cela se comprend ; mais de lle à faire de la baisse il y a un abime. Ea effet, en admettant même l'hypothèse que l'on semble redouter le plus, qu'y aurait-il de changé, même en Tarqoie ? Un homme, oai ; ane institation, non; un système financier encore moins. Il est impossible qu'en finance, ou tout au moins pour ce qui regarde les porteurs de la Dette Ottomane, il y ait quelque chose de changé. Le décret de Mo. harrem a mis cos porteurs à l'abri de tous les aléas: caprices de Saltan, ordres de succession au trône ou révolations de palais. La Commission internationale de la Dette fait simple. ment respecter eos droits, exerce, ane surveillance constante sur la perception des taxes et des impôts qu'elle administre et dont elle eat chargée de faire la répartition. Par conséquent, quoi qu'il arrive, aucune crainte sérieuse pour les portears, que le Sultan soit jeane on vieux, fils, on neveu de son guzerain bien portant og malade. Bref, pour les détentears, la santé du Padischah feat être considérée comme on accessoire ; leur "Saltan á 80x, c'est l'administration internationale de la Dotte."
Le lancement de Virginia", bateau-tourista de l'Express Nile Steamers Co. aura lieg demain, à 4 h. de l'après-midi, à l'arsenal da Bahr el Aïna, près da Pont des anglais, à Ghizeh.

Ce batean, construit d'après le type de ceux qui navigaent sur le Mississipi, a une longueur de 150 pieds et une largeur de 21. Toute la partie en avant da pont supérieur sora occupée par un grand salon entièrement vitré.
Le "Virginia" fora exclusivement le service entre Louxor et Assouan.
La lancement d'an autre bateau de la Com. paguio aura lieu très prochainement.

On annonce de Lyoxor que le Winter Palace Hotel, de l'Upper Egypt Hotels Co., sera il complètement terminé vers la fin da mois prochain, de sorte que ce grand établissement 4 poarra travailler toute la saison.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Ministère des Travaux Publics aura probablement besoin de s'aesorer, à titre temporaire, les services d'an bon sténograpbe et d'un bon dactylographe.
La connaissance parfaite des langues anglaise et frarçaise est indispensable.

Les personnes qui possèdent les qualités requises pourront adresser, jai qu'au 20 octob: 0 courant, au Service Administratif da Ministère des Travaax Publics, des demandes respectives indiquant leurs noms, prénoms, domiciles, ainsi que les appointements qu'elles désireraient obtenir.
Le Ministère ne prend, vis--vis des pétitionnaires, aucun engagement de quelque natare qu'il soit. 28676-3-2

div.head: ITALY'S DEFENCES.
LARGE SUMS TO BE SPENT.
div.p: The newspapers indicate that the Govern. ment is resolved to expend large sums on the army and navy, especially in purchasing new field artillery, to be supplied from Krapp's factory
(Reuter)

div.head: FRAULEIN KRUPP'S WEDDING.
ANOTHER SPEECH BY KAISER.
div.p: On the occasion of the wedding of Fraulein Krapp, £130,000 were distributed amongst the employés of the factory.
The Emperor William, in a characteristic speech at the wedding, said that he hoped that Krapp's factory would continue to farnish Germany with the world's best guns for offence and defence. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN TERRORISM.
SPLENDIDLY ORGANIZED BAND.
div.p: The police have discovered a splendidly organised band of terrorists which was governed with iron roles. They possessed their own police, and shot all suspects. It is stated that the band has perpetrated a long series of murders and robberies. Forty nine arrests have been made. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN RAILWAY COLLISION.
div.p: A railway collision has taken place at Oka. Six carriages were demolished and fire broke out amongst the debris. Ten bodies have been recovered. 30 persons were injured and many are missing. (Reuter)

div.head: TRADE AND THE ENTENTE CORDIALE.
div.p: The Committee of Commerce and Industry gave a banquet to the Lord Mayor of London. In the toasts proposed, it was said that com. merce must now strengthen and develop the political benefits of the Entente Cordiale. (H.)

div.head: SINKING OF SUBMARINE.
div.p: During the maræo vres, the submarine Latin disappeared at a depth of 40 metres. The Admiral is organising a search. The Governor of Malta is sending help. The Latin had on board a lieutenant and 14 men. (Havas)

div.head: NEW YORK ELECTORAL CAMPAIGN
div.p: The electoral campaign for the governorship of the city is being pursued with extraordinary vigour. Mr. Hearst, the Democratic candidate, is straining every nerve in order to ensure success. President Roosevelt has sent Mr. Root and other important political personages to sustain the Republican candidate, Mr. Hughes. (Reuter)

div.head: WINGATE COLLIERY EXPLOSION.
div.p: All the entombed miners in the Wingate colliery have been rescued. (Reuter)

div.head: PORT SAID ENGINE WORKS.
div.p: Dowrie & Co., Port Said, bave on hand a large quantity of boilers; engines, lathes, pumps, fan blasts, etc., etc.; also a large stock of cast Iron, about 20,000 second hand pipes spigot and faucet type in good condition 61" and 8" diameter. Owing to removal of Works these must be cleared. Offers at from Fcs. 60 per ton upwards (according to the article) will therefore be considered if received in time. Exceptional opportunity. Boilers are fully serviceable for steaming or at the price would make excellent storage tanks.
Don't miss this chance. No reasonable offer will be refused. 28656-15.A.-4

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTHOUSES.
REPORT FOR 1905.
div.p: From the statistics given at the end of the report by the Ports and Lighthouses Administration for 1995-issued nearly nine months after the close of the year--we gather that, during the period in question, the arrivals at the port of Alexandria were 1,817 steamers (3,296,237 tone) and 2,794 sailing vessels (295,044 tons) whilst the clearances were 1,816 steamers (3,274,842 tons) and 2,702 sailing vessels (278,145 tons). Compared with the year 1904.the increase was as follows:
Arrivals 81 steamers 313,943 tons
496 sailing vessels 69,347 ,,
Clearances 86 steamers 298,648 ,,
421 sailing vessels 52,867 ,,

The British arrivals numbered 801 steamers (1,521,879 tons) against 786 ships (1,340,439 tons) in 1904. The German arrivals showed an increase of 38 steamers and 140,875 tons, whilst the French returns were 31 steamers and 61,088 tons greater than in 1904. The Austrian figures were 145 steamers (310,668 tons) against 160 steamers (334,851 tons), being a decrease of 15 ships and 24,183 tons.

From the manufacturer and agent's point of view, we assume the most important parts of the report are those relating to the provision of new berthing accommodation, and to the steps which are being taken to lessen the congestion in the barbour. We, therefore, give the following particulars of certain work done during 1905.
Additional Quay Berths,

These berths, which are to form a continuation of the import quaye, will be each 120 metres long, with ample shed accommodation and railway facilities for the handling and storage of goods discharged from ships lying at them. The sheds will be 6 metres high, and 25 metres long, and capable of supporting a second story. About 65,200 cubic metres---out of the required 700,000 c.m.----had been dredged by the 31st December. It is expected that two of the new berths will be ready by July 1907, and another one in January 1908.
Now Collier Berths Quay A.

The greater part of the sea reclamation for redeeming the mole and throwing out an arm where the four collier berths were to be created was completed by the end of last year. In this connection the Director General states "As the credit of L.E. 50,000 accorded in 1903 is nearly exhausted, and that of LE 38,000 in 1905 will be spent daring the summer, I am asking for a farther credit of LE 40,000 tur 1906 to enable two more collier berths to be added to the four now in hand, and to prolong the arm so as to afford better protection to the colliers bertbed at Quay A.
Six Timber Berths at Gabbary.

In view of the length of time occupied in the discharging of timber ships and in the removal of the cargoes from the quays, it was decided to have all the work done in the outer harbour at Gabbary wberè 'not only can suffi. "cient berths for the discharge be provided, I"bat, what is of equal importance, ample space " for the handling of the timber ashore with "Means of transport by road and rail, as well "as for the necessary Customs operation of " measurement and valuation."
The contract for the new timber quays was 1st in October 1905 at LE. 137,000. By the 31st December 70,000 cubic metres of sea reclamation was effected.
New Cattle Port and Quay.

"This work has proceded rapidly, in spite of "the great difficulties encountered in placing " quay blocks by means of divers at a spot "exposed to the fall force of the seas and swell. " About 160 metres in length of the elbow "shaped quay,sixty feet wide, have been completed."
New Pass.

The new pass into the harbour-for which a grant of L.E. 100,000 has already been accorded—is to be 35 feet deep at low water with a width of 600 feet, thas being double the width and five feet deeper than the existing entrance. The work was commenced in June 1905, and should be fini-hed by the end of 1907 or even earlier.
General Maintenance.

"We have carried out in 1906 extensive repairs to the paving of the Quays, and to the sheds on Quay B. The artificial blocks on the sea side of the Breakwater damaged by sea and weather have been repaired with cement. The gradual substitution of stone quays for wooden jetties in the careening basin has been carried on this year, and will be completed in 1906. Drains to carry off the rain water in winter from the Quays, which were much wanted, have been laid."
The value of the work mentioned in the last paragraph will, we think, be fully appreciated by merchants at this end.
The observations on the working of the coal hoist installation in the port are sufficiently interesting to warrant us giving them "in extenso."

" During 1905, we have discharged 259,000 tons of coal by means of the three pairs of coal hoists as follows. 220,000 tons for the Railway Administration, 39,000 tons for individual marchants. In 1904 the total 80 discharged was 266,000 tons, of which 218,000 were for the Railway Administration and 39,000 for individual merchants. The working of the machines has been most satisfactory, but the question of relative cost per ton discharged as compared with that of manual labour is not very greatly in favour of the hoists. The 259,000 tons discharged by the hoists cost L.E. 3,190, equivalent to the rate of L.E. 0,123 per ton ; our

uniform charge to Railway Administration "and merchants has been L.E. 0,025 por ton; the cost of discharge by hand is from L.E 0,015 to L.E. 0,025, according to the distance to which the coal has to be carried from the "ship to the coal store or railway wagon. The comparative rapidity is, however, greatly in favour of the hoists, and, consequently, the avoidance of demurrage in the

case of railway colliers, which according to charter party must be discharged at the rate of 750 tons per day ; whilst the constantly increasing difficulty of obtaining manual labour promises soon to bring the hoists into popular use, and we shall require to add to their number next year.
Sundry Works.
Amongst sundry works executed by the Chief Engineer of the Port on behalf of the Customs Administration were the following :
The building of a large magazine for the storage of oils -- other than petroleum-covering an area of 36,000 square metres and situated on the site of the old petroleum store.
The erection of a magazine covering an area of 600 square metres on Quay F.
The building of an annex to the inflammable store at Gabbary.

During the summer of 1905, Berthe Nos. 13 and 14, with two large sheds, were handed over to the Customs for general import purposes. When the work on Quay A-previously mentioned - is completed, the four berths and two sheds on Q 1ay B now used for coal will be rendered available for the general purposes of commerce.
The Director General ends his report thus :

" In conclusion, I may say, without fear of contradiction, that owing to the liberal grants made by the Financial Adviser for the facilitation of the general business of the Port of Alexandria, very extensive improvements have been inaugurated during the past year both as regards shipping and commerce, the results of which will become largely apparent in 1907, 1908, and 1909. By that time we shall have an excellent cattle port, six more collier berths, and four new general commerce berths with sheds, railways, machinery, etc., besides a complete protection for our outer harbour, with a now and easy pass through the reefs available in all weathers for ships of the largest class.”

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary free discussion.

div.head: ORIGIN OF KHEDIVIAL HYMN.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir.—Referring to "Musica's” letter in a recent issue of your valuable paper, may I trespass on your space and say that I have been told by old residents that the Khedivial Hymn is the Neapolitan Royal Hymn. An Italian offered this hymn as his own composition to Said Pasha, and was splendidly rewarded by him. In 1862, when Said Pasha went to Naples, it happened that his band played the Khedivial Hymn, and was arrested by the police for playing a forbidden Bourbonic tone, as ore may see in the papers of that time. I beg leave to remain, your obedient servant,

div.head: EDUCATION OF THE POOR.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.”
Sir, I have of late penned a few lines under the above heading, and to-day I contribute this letter to your venerable paper for the perusal of the Böglish-reading world.

In my previous letter I had stated that the charitable Society, Orwa Woska, had decided to dismiss all the non-paying papile, and I allege to-day that the matter has been put into force. The mothers and fathers of the miserable pupils made many endeavours that their children might be taken back to the schools, but their efforts were fruitless.

To illustrate the orgelty of this body of men who have taken over themselves the duty of teaching the community, I cite a story concerning the father of a papil. This msd, seeing that his son would be deprived of going to school, went to the members asking for their mercy. He was asked about his work as well as his pay. He indicated that he is a' daily-paid labourer of P.T. 8 in the Customs. He was told that it would be much better for him to tear his son an art or employ him in some place. The man, seeing that it was impossible to send his son back to the school, left them in despair.

How, my dear venerable reader, can a poor boy learn industries before knowing how to read and write, and where are the industrial schools for the poor. The Mobamed Ali industrial school is as yet in the lap of the nursery. How can such a boy be attached to any work, especially in the present day.

I turn now to our National Prese, which kept the secret from the public, and which feigns to be the only organ of reform. Instead of dealing in idle discussions like that which occurred between the "native" "Al Lewa" and the "professor" "Al Mosyad," it would be more interesting to convey to the public such important news. Such serious matter spread in all the parts of the city would at least attract some attention of the correspondents of these national journals, who, alas ! tarn a deaf ear to those who accused them.
I marvel at their silence ! Are they chloroformed or duped ? Or what?
If such were our case we would be sure of our retrogression.

Where is "Al Minbar” who feigos to be independent, free in his views and acting for the progress of the country ? Everyday we notice that the aim of these papers is to exaggerate matters whether wrong or right. Bat how in such & prodigious matter they are dumb I : If we tarn and have a glance at the past, we immediately perceive that the charitable institutes are becoming legs and less.
The Earl of Cromer, knowing the mainstay of our progress, invited the fellaheen to create kuttabs and establish elementary schools. No one can doubt that this is the only path to our happiness.

We hear now of the scheme of the University and the lavish subscriptions for it. I advise those who are holding the reins of the scheme to change the name of the "University" into the "Education of the Poor," who are the greater part of the people.
In conclusion I consider it most necessary that the Ministry of Public Instruction should lay its hands on the Orwa Woska Society and give as an explanatory note of its accounts.
Your Obedient Servant

div.head: Notice.
SUDAN GOVERNMENT
DISPOSAL OF BUILDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN.
div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender on the forms issued by the Sudan Government and must be received at Khartoum not late than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease,, will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to in. spection at the following places durg the usual business hours :
Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agriculture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor
of Khartoum Province.
Cairo : *Office of Sudan Agent (T).
Port Sudan: Office of Inspector (Government Office (T).
Suakin : Office of Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Damer : Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbara : Office of Director of Railways.
Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port Said : Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative.
London: *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute."
Suez : Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office

Representative. For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: GOUVERNMENT DU SOUDAN.
Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
AVIS
div.p: Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'en. viron 400 parcelles de terrains à bâtir à Port Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmentation de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à partir du ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l'expiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (à condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libro de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiques dont s'agit; ces offres devront I mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement dų Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécification du bail, seront à la disposition du Public à partir du ler Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*---Bureau du Directeur de l'A-] griculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire* - Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan*—Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakin---Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa---- Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa.
El-Da mer---- Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber.
Atbara-—Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie----Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Saïd----Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres—Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez---- Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels, les conditions d'adjudication et de concession, ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du ler Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés dins la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lettre majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande écrite adressée au Directeur de l'Agricultu re et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
Aux bureaux marqués d'uno astérisque, copies dos documents pourront être obtenues à partir du 12 Octobre 1906, moyonnant payoment do P.T. 5 ou un shelling par copie. 28497-2*-1

div.head: Administration des Chemis de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer et des.. Télégraphes de l'Eat a l'honneur de porter à la connaisance da public que le Baresa Télé graphique de San Stefano est fermé à partir d'aujourd'hai. 28674-2-2
Le Caire, le 15 Octobre 1906.
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer et Jes Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public que le Bureau Télégraphique de Mit-El-Abai est onvert à partir de ce jour pour l'échange ds correspondances en langues européennes et arabe.
Son horaire est de 8 h. am à 8 h. p.m. Les Dimanobes ds 8 h. a.m. à 1 h p.m. Le Caire, le 15 Octobre 1906. 28675-2-2
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer de 'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance la Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'an trente Octobre courant, à midi, des offres pour la fourni ture de 15,0 0 (qai ze mille) grands couffins, at 180,00 (cent quatre-vingt mille) petits Couffins à deux poig ées livrables par mensuslités de 1.250 (mille deux-cent cinquante) pour les grands couffins et 15,000 (quinze mille) pour les petits couffins, suivant les clauses et conditions du cahier des charges dont on peut obtenir copie contre paiement de cent milliè mes aux Magasins Généraux à Boulao (Caire) et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) on on peut aussi examiner les échantillons, chaque jour, de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m. les dimanches et les autres jours fériér 'xceptés.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire devra j indre à son offre un récépissé de ver ement de L.E. 50 (oir quante Livres Egypiennes) à titre de dépôt provisoire et soumetre un contre échantillon des couffins qu'il ropose de fournir.

Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a con arrence da 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de l'offre agréée et ce dans les vingt quatre heures de I'v's de l'acceptation qui lui sera communiqué à cet effet.
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'ane feaille de papier timbré de trente millièmes. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à:
Monsieur l'Ingénieur en Chef
de la Voie et des Travaux, Chemins de fer de l'Etat,
Le Caire,
et sous double enveloppe l'intérieure portant la uscription suivante:
"Offre pour grands et petit couffins à deux poignées."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse ni à donner saite anx soumissions présentées; elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 13 Octobre 1906. 18662-2-1
